specs/zed/approved/glance/instant_cachin.message: I think this would be better as "immediate", because you're proposing to do it as soon as possible, not instantaneously!
immediate caching of a given image
OK, so this won't be instantaneous if the queue is non-empty.  Might be worth mentioning that you can make the ``GET /v2/cache`` call to see the size of the queue.

This is a change from the current API, which is returning 200 (with an empty response body) for this:

https://opendev.org/openstack/glance/src/commit/cb65cc8e44523cd04ecace02296061a6ddc3982d/glance/tests/functional/v2/test_cache_api.py#L82

That being said, the original spec said this was supposed to be a 202:

https://opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs/blame/commit/2638ada23d92f714f54b71db00330e4a6c921beb/specs/xena/approved/glance/cache-api.rst#L153

I think we should file a bug for the incorrect response code (that is, change the response to a 202 immediately in master independently of this spec) and backport it to yoga and xena before anyone notices.

Ack, will report a bug and fix it right away.
I think we need to backport it to Yoga only since in yoga we have added this work.
formatting: need a blank line here

1) Why didn't we implement this feature this way from the start? Was there a technical reason that prevented us from doing so?

2) If there are a lot of images to be cached in the queue, doesn't that prevent one specific image from being immediately cached?

1. Initially glance cache was not part of API and it was managed by external tool called as glance-cache-prefetcher, later when we moved the caching operations to API we moved this prefetcher part as a periodic job which is currently running after specific intervals (which is not in end users hand).

2. So to avoid this part we are now modifying any API to immediately trigger caching if it is not running or else add the image to the queue which can be picked later for caching. If the operation is already in progress then yes it's not very immediate caching, but also it will not wait until next periodic run (which we don't know how much time admin has configured for the same)

s/ensure to//

sounds a little more native

This is actually not a change right? As far as the user was concerned, queuing an image means it could start caching at any moment. If we had our interval set very low, or we got lucky, the image would seem to start immediately from our perspective.

So I think if it were me, I'd say this has "No REST API impact" and position this as purely a backend behavioral difference. Your codes below still indicate "202: I'll start caching this at some point" so...
Are these any different from the existing behavior?

s/will be/is and will remain/

..right? no change with this.
My point was that it's misspelled :)
and specifically "will be testable with this change, where it currently isn't really"

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Thanks for doing this Brian. It might have been (or still be) helpful to arrange the options as a set of patches, starting with the base, and then modifying the files for the various options so we can see the diff in a browser. I downloaded this and diff'd the tick2.rst and tick2-manual.rst files to get a sense of what you added manually.

Unsurprisingly, I think the -manual version most closely resembles what I had in mind, although there's still quite a bit in there that I would have left out if I were doing it. It's clear that a lot of it is opinion about what is important, and maybe there's some cinder context about the important things that I don't have. Some thoughts:

In the prelude, the deprecation reminder makes sense to me, and I'm guessing it's been in multiple cycles' notes already? I think this sort of thing is also why I would expect that just a blind merge would be a problem. If tick2 is where you're going to actually drop the thing that has been deprecated for many cycles, a blind merge would have that deprecation reminder from the tock, as well as "okay we finally did it" from tick2. The three API notes there (two microversions and a response update) seem like too much detail to me -- I would expect a lot of operators gloss over those normally anyway.

In the new features section, I guess it seems like calling out all the new driver-specific features is too much. However, since it seems like that section is just as full as it is in the tick2-plus-tock.rst version, I guess that means you think it's critical to have that stuff in there. Minor features from drivers that only a subset of people use would be a good "if you care about all the features added, be sure to check out the previous tock release notes" link item in my opinion. Obviously the policy thing is big and important to bring forward I think, as it impacts everyone and it's maybe even more significant than *just* being a new feature.

Known issues are probably good candidates for bringing forward, along with upgrades, and deprecations.

The things in "Other notes" seem too minor to be worth the noise to me, but maybe that's just lack of context.

All that said, the -manual version renders to not an insane amount of text, even with the uncharacteristically lengthy policy section. So maybe it's the right amount of detail, I dunno.

Fits with backport criteria and worth fixing change in stable branch!
Thank you Rajat!

Hi , 
The main assumption here is that we use tempest keypair to allocate the ecdsa private/public key ,
The tempest ssh also support ssh with file_key (~/.home/stack/.ssh) location.

We should assume that tempest plugins may ssh to others without keypair but from file_key path,
Means that we may allocate the ecdsa keys on local machine.

Is it cirros issue ? or paramiko code issue ?
I am ok with this, just waiting for +A if Benny Kopilov concern is resolved now and it is ok to merge it?

recheck, seems keystone stuck somewhere. "tempest.lib.exceptions.IdentityError: Got identity error
"
Hi, it is probably cirros issue. See cirros github issue here: https://github.com/cirros-dev/cirros/issues/77
it's cirros, not paramiko, that's correct, long story short, paramiko>2.8.1 uses rsa-sha2, cirros doesn't support that (yet) and as a workaround ecdsa keys can be used.

Cirros does not support rsa-sha2 , so the problem is with cirros image and not with paramiko code.
i hope that my question is in place but why do we run cirros version that does not support sha2 ? 
Is it possible to use other OS version from devstack (default , small that support sha2)

plugins/modules/identity_domain_info.py.message:
Your code exactly behaves as the previous code.

Unfortunately, the previous code duplicates code from the sdk and behaves differently than what is documented. For example, it looks like the filters doc "A dictionary of meta data to use for further filtering" was copied from another module because it is not correct. In Yoga's SDK the filters dict is used to construct query args when listing domains (and no name was given) and not to filter results after they have been received (which other search_* functions do).

https://opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk/src/branch/stable/yoga/openstack/cloud/_identity.py#L890

The issue is now that 'filters' has different semantics than in other modules. Which sucks. We could rename 'filters' to 'query'/'args'/'query_args' or something to highlight the difference to other modules. Or we could change our behavior here to match that of other modules. Not sure what is best. Any ideas?

The "solution" was to pass parameter name as 'name_or_id' to search_domains(). Then we can drop the whole if clause. This is possible because the new sdk does replicate the same logic inside and returns proxy objects.
Please convert to dict before returning domains.
Should we change this to domains? Or it can be done in a later patch also.
We can change that later in a separate patch which drops openstack_ prefixes from all modules.

Can we avoid doing this? If you look at pretty much all other ConfigObject subclasses, you'll see that we don't pass in arbitrary kwargs. Instead, we create the object and set the properties after, e.g.

  feature = vconfig.LibvirtConfigCPUFeature()
  feature.name = 'tsx'
  feature.policy = 'require'

So the '__init__' for this should look like:

  def __init__(self, **kwargs):
      super().__init__(root_name='feature', **kwargs)
      self.name = None
      self.policy = 'require'

There is some history in this :) In past almost every project used install_command and upper constraints in it. And some places there were extra constraints file linked (like lower-constraints.txt; yeah i know, it's past now) in deps, but pip only consider the 1st constraints file (which caused multiple problems). Then most of the projects (?) removed install_command and only used deps for list there everything (constraints, requirements).

For now: it does not matter where we use the constraints (afaik) it could be either in install_command or deps, but not in both. In that sense you are right if I'm not mistaken that install_command is used in develop-inst phase as well, so then there's no need to explicitly add requirements.txt in any tox target. The only question is: is there other reason why it is not fortunate to define install_command? (I really remember it was discouraged to use it, but don't know other details... but maybe i'm wrong)

Nevertheless, I'm OK with both ways (both solves the problem), so let me know and I update the patch accordingly. o:)

Thanks @Brian for the answer. I did a quick search and it seems that install_command was recommended only due to practical reasons [1]:

"Some projects have upper-constraints.txt in install_command but
explicitly override it in lower-constratints.txt this works and wont be
changed at this point but ideally all projects will use the same format
to reduce the impact in switching between projects."

I don't have hard feeling for the solution, so let this issue just be fixed for now. I've updated the patch according your suggestion. Thanks again for the review!

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-May/006478.html

My memory of the install_command removal was that we were discouraged from using it when the lower-constraints job was introduced (because obviously, it would make that job not work correctly).  However, in cinder or cinderlib, after wasting many developer-hours, we finally realized that what we really needed to do was keep the -c upper-constraints.txt in the install_command for the base testenv, and override it to be the non-constrained install_command for the special-purpose lower-constraints job (which most projects have removed at this point).

Anyway ... the problem was really hard to track down, and we only found it because there was a new release of some dependency that broke one of our CI jobs, even though that version was explicitly excluded by upper-constraints.

BTW, I'm pretty sure the constraints can be both in deps and in the install command; the key thing is that if the constraints are *not* in the install command, they aren't used in the usedevelop install.  We were discouraged from defining them in 2 places just because that's always a problem when updating things (you might miss one).

In summary, I'm not -2ing this, but I'm not +2 on it either.

@Elod: thanks for tracking down the history on this!  Good to know that there's no technical reason against this change.

LGTM and Zuul is happy, so let's merge it!

nova/context.py.message: I'm wondering why previously we created a copy from the exception instead of storing it directly.

Meant to add this yesterday for posterity:

I talked to dansmith and sean-k-mooney [1] and they found the specific reason a new exception object was created here (in Stein) is because of an issue in python2 where a traceback object would never be garbage collected because it contains references to stack frames that were active when the exception was raised [2][3], creating a circular reference [4]. This issue was fixed in python3 [5][6], presumably version 3.3 as a warning in the docs [7] about the circular reference was removed in the version 3.3 docs [8].

[1] https://meetings.opendev.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2022-05-03.log.html#t2022-05-03T16:45:24
[2] https://stackoverflow.com/questions/44681681/what-could-prevent-a-traceback-from-being-garbage-collected
[3] https://stackoverflow.com/questions/1658293/why-is-there-a-need-to-explicitly-delete-the-sys-exc-info-traceback
[4] https://peps.python.org/pep-0344/#open-issue-garbage-collection
[5] https://peps.python.org/pep-3110/#semantic-changes
[6] https://mail.python.org/pipermail/python-3000/2007-January/005363.html
[7] https://docs.python.org/3.2/library/sys.html#sys.exc_info
[8] https://docs.python.org/3.3/library/sys.html#sys.exc_info

I should have linked this earlier but wasn't sure if people would be interested, this is the only evidence I found of why it was being copied:

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/607934/1/nova/context.py#446

and that comment was removed in PS2 and the comment was not discussed anywhere on the review ... so I googled around to see if there is some kind of scoping problem with assigning a caught exception object to a new variable and could find nothing about potential problems.

The only thing I found is that if you refer to "e" outside (after) the try-except block without assigning it to a new variable, there is different behavior between python 2 and 3 where in one case it doesn't go out of scope and in one it does:

 $ cat t.py 
 try:
     raise Exception('foo')
 except Exception as e:
     print(e)

 print(e)

 $ python2 t.py 
 foo
 foo

 $ python3 t.py 
 foo
 Traceback (most recent call last):
   File "t.py", line 6, in <module>
     print(e)
 NameError: name 'e' is not defined

Whereas after assigning to new variable:

 $ cat t.py 
 try:
     raise Exception('foo')
 except Exception as e:
     err = e
     print(err)

 print(err)

 $ python2 t.py 
 foo
 foo

 $ python3 t.py 
 foo
 foo

The only other place I see this pattern is from the same patch in a different file:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blame/b8cc5704558d3c08fda9db2f1bb7fecb2bcd985d/nova/compute/multi_cell_list.py#L112

I was thinking to ask Dan if he knows anything about it bc he uploaded some of the PS in that review.
Yet another reason to add copious NOTE comments when doing weird stuff like this. Thanks for chasing this down, Mel

Actually, this modification should not be required because the role is limited to hosts with openvswitch. What is your inventory?

We can't delete the comments either.

Please have a look at this more thorough patch: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla-ansible/+/840895
and try it out.

In your case, you can live without any fix, if you simply switch from reconfiguring neutron to reconfiguring loadbalancer group, i.e. put all neutron nodes in network and move network nodes to loadbalancer. You want to have control+loadbalancer on the same hosts but openstack networking elsewhere.

By the way, why do you put neutron network services on so many hosts?

Anyways, the problem arises from the following:

The openvswitch role is defined as follows:

[openvswitch:children]
network
compute
manila-share

But on the defaults/main.yml file of the role we can see:
openvswitch_services:
  openvswitch-db-server:
    container_name: "openvswitch_db"
    image: "{{ openvswitch_db_image_full }}"
    enabled: "{{ enable_openvswitch }}"
    group: openvswitch
    host_in_groups: >-
      {{  
      inventory_hostname in groups['compute']
      or (enable_manila_backend_generic | bool and inventory_hostname in groups['manila-share'])
      or inventory_hostname in groups['neutron-dhcp-agent']
      or inventory_hostname in groups['neutron-l3-agent']
      or inventory_hostname in groups['neutron-metadata-agent']
      }}

So OVS runs in compute nodes and nodes that run neutron agents, but the openvswitch role is applied to all network nodes, here lies the inconsistency.

I. Overview

II. Architecture diagram

III. Making Designate highly available

1. Deploy each of the designate services on two or more different nodes.

2. Ensure that the designate services can access OpenStack messaging from every node.

3. Run the instances of designate-api behind a load balancer. In designate.conf, ensure that the following is set:

   [service:api]
   api_base_uri = http://<load balancer URI>/
   enable_host_header = True
   ...
   [oslo_middleware]
   enable_proxy_headers_parsing = true

4. Confirm that your load-balancer software is properly configured. For example, confirm that you enable `mod_proxy` in Apache.

5. Set a coordination backend_url to prevent periodic tasks being run more than once. The back-end URL must point to a DLM (Distributed Lock Manager) that is supported by tooz, a distributed helper library that supports group membership. See tooz driver list for available drivers. In designate.conf set the following:

   [coordination]
   backend_url = kazoo://<zookeeper url>:<zookeeper port>

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
> Patch Set 1:
> 
> This basically changes "no valid host was found" from always fatal to never fatal.  Is that really the case?

The no valid host errors are returned by Nova when its placement service is unable to find a valid location to place a VM. In a typical deployment of openstack this means that either Nova is truly full up or that there is an accounting error of some kind that requires cloud operator intervention. In my opinion it is desireable in both cases to have Nodepool return an error so that we can try to schedule the node in another provider or if there are no other providers bubble up the NODE_FAILURE so that people can look into why the cloud isn't operating as expected.

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> This basically changes "no valid host was found" from always fatal to never fatal.  Is that really the case?

Unfortunately, I inherited this change, so I'm not exactly sure. It seems we were occasionally getting that error when spinning up nodes; speculation was that it happened when the quota was changed after the node started spinning up, but this was never confirmed.

I'd be willing to try without that particular part of the change and try to sort out whats going on if we can figure out an upstream way to keep retrying when there is no quota.

> I'd be willing to try without that particular part of the change and try to sort out whats going on if we can figure out an upstream way to keep retrying when there is no quota.

This seems much safer. Currently nodepool will pause when it hits no quota and wait for quota to free up. But if we retry during that pause we shouldn't change the functional behavior of nodepool very much. We'll just do some extra API calls but that shouldn't be a big deal.

Old Behavior:

  Boot node
  Get quota error
  Pause
  Delete used node freeing quota
  Unpause
  Boot node

New Behavior:

  Boot node
  While quote error
    Sleep
  Boot node
Is this what you had in mind?

This feels a bit clunky particularly since I'm not sure this is a standard feature of openstack. However, nodepool has long worked around provider specific behaviors to the benefit of users so this seems to fall in line with that history.

doc/source/openstack.rst.message: The name of this option and the description seems overly prescriptive.  Really what this option does is cause quota errors to not be treated as fatal for the provider (and so node requests will be continually retried).  Could we change the name and description to match that, rather than the specific scenario that you want to use it for?  I think it would be okay to also describe your use case in the docs if you want.

nodepool/driver/openstack/handler.py.message:
I think this long sleep is why the testing fails. We probably check states before this sleep is completed.

As far as implementing the sleep I wonder if we need to do a hybrid between the current pause and the sleeping with retries to ensure we don't end up with a provider that grabs all the node requests but they fail for a long time due to quota errors. Something like having the first node to hit a quota error continue to retry but pause all other requests? That should provide the request pressure you want against the API while also avoiding having a single provider take all requests then fail to service them due to quotas.

We also need to take into consideration that we raise here for a reason which is to release the node request and give a different provider on a different cloud the chance to fulfill the node request. The reason for this is that otherwise we'd block the request until it can be satisfied while having free resources on a different cloud. This can be especially an issue on small multi-cloud systems.

I did some digging, and I don't think it would take all the requests. My understanding from reading the code is that only the requests that race in `_waitForNodeSet` checking the quota would enter this loop. The requests after that will automatically pause the handler (especially since we invalidate the quota cache). I don't think any "pausing" is necessary here since the code in `_waitForNodeSet` handles that already; the only thing we could *maybe* do here is try and detect if multiple threads are in this loop because of quota reasons and kick all but one out.... but this seems complex and error prone so I'd rather not unless it's a huge problem to have a few nodes in the loop until quota is satisfied (realizing that it won't consume all nodes because of the reasons stated above).


If my understanding is incorrect, please let me know :)

Right, I'm not sure how to reconcile those two; our setup needs the quota pressure to get the quote increased, but another setup might want to fall through to another provider... I'm not sure how to saitisfy both constraints since they seem contradictory; I hate to add a configuration option to control the behavior, but it's all I can really think of right know.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: afaik, only for older releases - el9 as well as el8 don't seem to have it anymore
the -e check will handle /var/lib/dbus/machine-id not being there.
Ack

Well, it's not that clear:
"If by any of the above rules, a first boot is detected, units with ConditionFirstBoot=yes will be run."

Sooo... empty file is still triggering ConditionFirstBoot=yes things.

But it's probably better to be on the safest side, that machine-id thing is one of those over-engineered things anyway.
Note the "/etc/machine-info" that exists now, showing yet another machine-id - though it's apparently not always present, and apparently has no actual impact on the real machine-id content.

The machine-id docs are correct I think, they say this which matches with my observed behaviour:

  If /etc/machine-id exists and is empty, a boot is not considered the first boot. systemd will still bind-mount a file containing the actual machine-id over it and later try to commit it to disk (if /etc/ is writable).

> Sooo... empty file is still triggering ConditionFirstBoot=yes things.

Not according to my testing on centos9 :(

I can see in the journal [systemd] generating the machine-id, but units with ConditionFirstBoot=yes do not run. The context for this change is https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-image-elements/+/837430

if the doc isn't correct (or, well, the implementation)... That's a bug that should be reported then (against systemd?) imho. The conditions listed in the doc are precise and really tell any of them would trigger an actual FirstBoot :/

/me lets coffee kick in..... *ding*!

you're right. But it sounds so wrong :(. So basically, the "workaround" for the virt-sysprep and virt-customize aren't correct (add --truncate /etc/machine-id).... How NOT convenient. Guess I'll have to rework a bit my things in the lab.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
I kind of wondered why I'd not heard of this because I remember reading that page, but time flies 😊

AFAICS this came in with

https://github.com/systemd/systemd/commit/3023f2fead7df9f219acf3c8595d974e31ad23cc

If I'm reading that right, that means systemd 247 is the first release that supports this?

centos 8 seems to be at 239; focal 245 ... so we have a lot of distros that won't know what is going on?

I'm concerned that these are all thinking their machine-id is "uninitalized" and that doesn't matter in testing here where everything is ephemeral, but may cause issues when we bring up more hosts? 

I'm not 100% sure it's *not* backwards compatible, but reading around I couldn't see anything say it explicitly was.  Only -1 as I think this is worth double-checking and noting one way or the other ... if it's not, probably a "systemctl --version" check would work?

I chased it down a little further ...

The acutal code seems to be https://github.com/systemd/systemd/commit/583cef3b7347c4e6ca269d38efef6d2e4314aba6 ... not the other one i said

I did double check at https://git.centos.org/rpms/systemd/blob/c7/f/SOURCES none of this got backported

The bit that has been there for many years is https://github.com/systemd/systemd/blob/da13d2ca0731b413841663052f2cc6832a855334/src/shared/machine-id-setup.c#L130 which generates a fresh machine-id if it reads something that isn't a 128-bit uuid.  So this must be what it has fallen into?

I'm just a bit worried that the existence of a file might have other issues.  AFAICS from the logs, the problems we've had before have not so much been the existence of the file, but that they had a uuid in them already.  so maybe "invalid value" == "no file"?  if we're convinced it is, i guess we can go with this.  we should probably make a note inline about this though.

I've just checked the behaviour on centos7/systemd-219, it looks like the "uninitalized" behaviour itself has existed for some time and the above commit makes use of that:

  $ echo uninitialized > /etc/machine-id
  $ reboot
  ...
  $ cat /etc/machine-id 
  76686998bcc84f079f661c1d29f03518
  $ systemctl --version
  systemd 219
  +PAM +AUDIT +SELINUX +IMA -APPARMOR +SMACK +SYSVINIT +UTMP +LIBCRYPTSETUP +GCRYPT 
  +GNUTLS +ACL +XZ +LZ4 -SECCOMP +BLKID +ELFUTILS +KMOD +IDN
  $ cat /etc/redhat-release 
  CentOS Linux release 7.8.2003 (Core

I'll follow up with a note about why this works on older vs newer systemd.

Remember though, the current behaviour is to truncate /etc/machine-id, rather than no file. So in relation to the documented first boot semantics, we were triggering 3., now we're triggering 2.

[1] https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/machine-id.html#First%20Boot%20Semantics
I'm happy with the note and what we've looked into.  If we do have an issue, we've got a good head-start on it

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: I confirm that this helps and we tested it together in a real environment.

Some questions:
- what is OVN doing with the baremetal ports traffic?
- do we need to spawn a DHCP agent?
Perfect, so those are "similar" to SRIOV ports. Now I have a better picture.

Q: what is OVN doing with the baremetal ports traffic?

With the external ports we know reply to ARPs from the baremetal node, as well allows it to access the OVN metadata agent. Just like SR-IOV nodes would.

Q: do we need to spawn a DHCP agent?

Yes, we need to have the Neutron DHCP agent running on the OpenStack controller nodes to serve the baremetal node with DHCP and allows it to chainload from PXE to iPXE.

In a soon feature we want this to be handled by OVN controller itself, but at the moment the chainloading part is not fully implemented yet.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Is the intention to run it more often or less often?

IIUC by moving it to the nova_virtqemud container it will only be run during a deploy if something about that container config changes (e.g update to a new image).

However it would also run on every host restart which could be an issue. Walking the /var/lib/nova tree could be time consuming in some cases (e.g busy NFS servers).

If the intention is to only run on an image update then just removing TRIPLEO_DEPLOY_IDENTIFIER from the env vars for the current container would be a safer approach I think.

The intention was to "sanitize" and auto-heal if any broken permissions in /var/lib/nova upon each start of the service. I expected that would improve situation with fixing breakages after manual virsh/qemu-img actions done by users, also fixing wrong permissions caused by NFS misconfiguration, for example. I'm not sure if this feature would be feasible though, so  am looking for your feedback.
@Oliver, WDYT? Does this make sense? Or should we keep the things as is?

IIRC This was initially added to ensure the correct ownership when services switched from host to containers. A simple recursive chown nova:nova could not be used - it caused issues for open files that were owned by qemu (or maybe the owner was root).

It evolved to ensure the selinux context is correct too. I don't recall why this was necessary - Tengu knows the details I believe.

If these reasons are no longer valid I think we should remove it completely.

If a user messes up permissions manually or forgets to set norootsquash I think they should be responsible for fixing it. Perhaps we could just document it or provide an example script.

kuryr_kubernetes/controller/service.py.message: Ten minutes could be a bit to long to wait. Perhaps it should be shortened to maybe one minute or two?
this might be too frequent, I think 10 mins is good.

If we have 10 minutes to wait, while we have request burst for creating like 100 pods (which implies 100 neutron ports), which may create leftover ports due to the load, and keeping in mind cleaning may be interrupted by the neutron failures, than it may happen that cleaning up procedure is slower, than creating leftovers.

Also please note, that we need to wait to dead port have age older than 10 minutes before removing - which means, that with 10 minutes periodic task, we will need to wait up between 10 and 20 minutes before we send the delete request.

kuryr_kubernetes/utils.py.message: This translates to 15 minutes. I guess, that it should be enough time to create a port.
might be better to rename it to network_id

Kuryr ports are first created with device-owner "compute:kuryr"[1], let's make sure to also include that here if no Network ID is passed.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/kuryr-kubernetes/blob/42ae6a37ab4257c1dafad5bc48c456f7a58e34e9/kuryr_kubernetes/controller/drivers/nested_vlan_vif.py#L176
actually even if with Network ID, it might be safer to use it.
Maybe not-tags query parameter can be used instead?

Wait, if we're looking for ports without tags we can't just query without a network_id - we might list ports created by different Kuryr instances in the same tenant, which is supported. And deleting dead ports owned by a different Kuryr is probably fine, but I guess we still want to keep a scope here.

We either got to have a list of network ids taken from KuryrNetworks or query Neutron for networks with our tags. I obviously prefer querying K8s API. ;)

Now thinking about it I noticed device_id field on ports that seems to allow putting anything in there. I wonder if we could put cluster ID there instead of using tags.

The KUryrNetwork CRs have the network ID defined.
https://github.com/openstack/kuryr-kubernetes/blob/master/kubernetes_crds/kuryr_crds/kuryrnetwork.yaml#L47-L48

That would be great, if we could grab the network ids from crds. but there is no such information on kuryrnetwork crd :/ Now, I'm torn between leaving such a hole for exploit this functionality and querying neutron every 1.5 minute for list of tagged networks.

This is a very good point, Michal. We gotta get the network IDs

If we can query Ports by description, I think we could add the tags there later.

Oh crap, you're right.

> Now thinking about it I noticed device_id field on ports that seems to allow putting anything in there. I wonder if we could put cluster ID there instead of using tags.

Well, that was my thinking regarding not using tags at all (we could get rid of the headache of dealing with additional sub-sequential call to neutron for putting tag for the resource) either using description field for marking "our" resources, or some other. And we already agreed to use uid of the ns in description for net and subnet, so that device_id could be another field, which we could use. And BTW, device_id is used to hold VM id (or server id if you will), so it might be a better idea to bind all the resources which particular namespace have (so: let's put there namespace id), and as for "tags", we might use description field. WDYT?
Ah, even worse, if we have 2 envs `clusterID=foo` and `clusterID=bar`, `not_tags="clusterID=bar"` will list us all the ports having `clusterID=foo`. This isn't great.
IMO, A configuration option is better than a constant value.

I concur, we have way too much timeout options in the config that could only scare users. 10 minutes is a totally reasonable value, if Neutron won't move a port/subport to ACTIVE in 10 minutes, then we have a problem with Neutron.
No need to scare users here here, KuryrNetwork can be in a process of having a network created for it and that's perfectly normal. IMO debug is enough, or even just skipping logging.
This could be a warning though.

Based on this spec, it appears like Wireless FEC Operator has advanced configuration capabilities compared to existing solution.  Is there a reason deprecating (and removing) existing solution is not proposed?
Hi Greg, yes that's correct.
Yes. The current/default method is a simple configuration method and also need backward compatibility. Hence, no plans to deprecate at least for the current devices.

I believe the reasoning was for backwards compatibility and the fact that the existing mechanism acts as a simple default configuration solution.

Mouli / Steve ?   was there another reason.

I know for the N3000, there was a quirk with the device in that it required a device reset -- called by puppet which would eventually call into https://opendev.org/starlingx/config/src/branch/master/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/fpga_agent/reset_n3000_fpgas.py#L94

Do you know whether the N3000 would do the same?

I'm also thinking of the case where the operator is installed.  If we could detect that, there might be no need for puppet to do the PF/VF bind + reset.  Although it may not have a bad effect, it would be doing the operation twice

FEC Operator does the PF and VF interface binding and reset before applying configuration.
As you mention, I didn't see any issue in attempting to bind/rebind and reset twice during the configuration method change. IMHO, each solution should start with bind+reset+configure irrespective of what has been done by other.
I would prefer to not to change any steps in puppet.

The other thing StarlingX provides for the N3000 is the ability to write/rewrite the FPGA device image + retimer.  Do you know whether this can be done via the operator as well, or is it just the higher level configuration as above?

FEC operator does only the configuration part of the device. 
Does not perform the FPGA image operations.

also, yes! testing will cover the CRD delete and reconfigure while the application POD are running and its impact.
